metadata.description: Depreciation detail for Private Residential, Nonprofit, and Government sectors
sources: BEA Fixed Assets Accounts Tables, September 2025 update (data through 2024)
BEA NIPA Handbook Chapter 6 (residential structure types)
BEA NIPA Handbook Chapter 9 (government consumption expenditures)
BEA Detailed Fixed Assets Tables 2.4 (residential by type and ownership)
metadata.scaling_note: BEA proportions applied to Sankey model parent values ($750B residential, $500B nonprofit, $700B government). Actual BEA 2024 totals differ due to GDP model scaling.

children.name: Single-Family Permanent
children.source: BEA Detailed Fixed Assets Table 2.4: 1-unit structures are ~57% of residential depreciation. BEA data shows owner-occupied housing is ~72% of household CFC (B2607C/W279RC = 629.5/878.3).

children.name: Multi-Family
children.source: BEA Detailed Fixed Assets Table 2.4: Multi-unit structures are ~29% of residential structure depreciation. Split between small (2-4 unit) and large (5+ unit) buildings based on housing stock composition.

children.name: Other Residential
children.source: BEA Detailed Fixed Assets Table 2.4: Includes manufactured homes, improvements, brokers' commissions, and other residential structures (dormitories, etc.).

children.name: Equipment & Other
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets: Residential equipment and IP are a very small share (~2.5%) of residential depreciation. Includes appliances, fixtures embedded in rental properties.

nonprofit.name: Nonprofit Institutions
nonprofit.source: BEA NIPA: Households & Institutions CFC ($878.3B) minus Owner-occupied housing ($629.5B) = $248.8B for non-housing household/institution CFC. Nonprofit NPISH sector estimated at ~28% of total household & institution CFC based on BEA sector accounts. Scaled to $500B for Sankey model.

children.name: Structures
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets: Nonprofit structures ~36% of nonprofit CFC. Includes educational, health care, religious, and social service buildings.

children.name: Equipment
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets: Nonprofit equipment ~24% of nonprofit CFC. Medical and scientific equipment dominates due to hospital sector.

children.name: Intellectual Property
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets: Nonprofit IP ~40% of nonprofit CFC. R&D dominates due to university and medical research. Software share growing rapidly.

government.name: Government
government.source: BEA NIPA: Total government CFC = $803.8B (Federal $393.4B + S&L $410.4B). Scaled to $700B for Sankey model. Federal/S&L ratio: 48.9%/51.1%.

children.name: Federal
children.source: FRED A918RC1A027NBEA: Federal CFC = $393.4B (2024). Defense/nondefense split: B432RC=$209.7B defense, B546RC=$169.7B nondefense (general government portion).

children.name: Defense
children.source: FRED B432RC1A027NBEA: Defense CFC = $209.7B (2024). BEA: ~55% equipment (aircraft, ships, vehicles), ~15% structures (bases, installations), ~23% IP (weapons R&D, software). Defense represents 53% of federal CFC.

children.name: Defense Structures
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4: Defense structures ~15% of defense CFC. Includes military bases, installations, airfields, shipyards.

children.name: Defense Equipment
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4: Defense equipment ~62% of defense CFC. Dominated by aircraft, missiles, ships, and military vehicles with high depreciation rates.

children.name: Defense IP
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4 and FRED Y091RC: Defense IP ~23% of defense CFC. Weapons systems R&D is the dominant component.

children.name: Nondefense
children.source: FRED B546RC1A027NBEA: Nondefense CFC = $169.7B (2024). BEA: ~48% IP (R&D at NASA/NIH/DOE, software), ~24% equipment, ~28% structures. Nondefense represents 43% of federal CFC.

children.name: Nondefense Structures
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4: Nondefense structures ~29% of nondefense CFC. Includes federal office buildings, conservation facilities, postal facilities.

children.name: Nondefense Equipment
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4: Nondefense equipment ~24% of nondefense CFC. Includes vehicles, IT equipment, scientific instruments.

children.name: Nondefense IP
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4 and FRED Y091RC: Nondefense IP ~48% of nondefense CFC. Dominated by federal R&D spending at NIH, NASA, DOE, and government software systems.

children.name: State & Local
children.source: FRED A919RC1A027NBEA: State & Local CFC = $410.4B (2024). BEA: ~60% structures (highways, schools, water systems), ~24% equipment, ~16% IP. S&L represents 51% of total government CFC.

children.name: Structures
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4: S&L structures ~60% of S&L CFC. Infrastructure dominates: highways/streets are the single largest category, followed by educational buildings and water/sewer systems.

children.name: Highways & Streets
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets: Highways & streets are ~40% of S&L structures CFC. Includes interstates (federal-aid), state highways, local roads, bridges, and tunnels.

children.name: Educational Buildings
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets: Educational structures are ~23% of S&L structures CFC. Public K-12 schools dominate, with higher education a smaller share.

children.name: Water & Sewer Systems
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets: Water supply and sewage/waste disposal are ~19% of S&L structures CFC.

children.name: Other S&L Structures
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets: Remaining S&L structures include public safety, hospitals, transit, parks. Each relatively small individually.

children.name: Equipment
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4: S&L equipment ~24% of S&L CFC. Transit vehicles, IT equipment, construction machinery, and public safety vehicles.

children.name: Intellectual Property
children.source: BEA Fixed Assets Table 5.4 and FRED Y091RC: S&L IP ~16% of S&L CFC. Software is the largest component, followed by university-based R&D.
